body:
See https://bugs.python.org/issue45122

The appropriate *internal* C API is _PyCode_New, which takes a struct containing various (sometimes optional) arguments. We will try not remove fields from the struct (but it *is* an internal API).

You might also want to see if PyCode_NewEmpty does what you want.

Stefan Behnel is aware of this.

comment_data.body: Update: It's probably better to use PyCode_NewEmpty followed by code.replace(): https://docs.python.org/dev/library/types.html#types.CodeType.replace
Turns out, the problem with `PyCode_NewEmpty()` is that it takes `char*` arguments, not Python strings…
Do you need help finding a better way?

If we were going down the `.replace` route (which is a Python call) then we could equally do a direct call to the `types.CodeType` constructor? They should have similar overhead, right?

I guess it is a de-optimization from what we have now, but it avoids the need to have a global code object that's then replaced repeatedly.

> If we were going down the `.replace` route (which is a Python call) then we could equally do a direct call to the `types.CodeType` constructor? They should have similar overhead, right?

Yeah, we could call `PyCode_Type` (or its `tp_new()`), but that would require passing almost all arguments into it, so we'd still depend on the exact signature (or at least the list of required arguments, if we pass keyword arguments as a dict).

`.replace()` is a somewhat simple vectorcall with only the keyword arguments that we really need. But it requires keyword arguments (although we can prepare the constant keyword name tuple) and Python object arguments, which slows things down. Probably not as much as calling the type with a full dict, though.

Since we're caching code objects, I think we can afford adding a bit of overhead to their creation. It slows down the module import a little bit, as well as first-time creations at need. Profiling [already uses](https://github.com/cython/cython/blob/aea4e6b84b38223c540266f8c57093ee2039f284/Cython/Utility/Profile.c#L310) `PyCode_NewEmpty()` and we might be able to tweak [traceback creation](https://github.com/cython/cython/blob/aea4e6b84b38223c540266f8c57093ee2039f284/Cython/Utility/Exceptions.c#L721) into using that, too, with a bit of code duplication for newer Python versions.

Although the fact that we currently pass the function name and file name as  a `char*` into both of these internally seems like completely unnecessary overhead here – we have the Unicode string lying around anyway. The only issue is injecting the C code line into the "function name", to show it in tracebacks. If that's disabled, then `PyCode_NewEmpty()` would work there, as it currently stands, but would no longer work for us the next time we optimise the traceback creation overhead. (There's code out there that uses exceptions extensively and not just for exceptional cases.) Function object creation uses the constant Unicode string objects.

So, it's either slow, Python-level keyword arguments (calling `PyCode_Type` or `.replace()`), or fast, version specific C code (calling `_PyCode_New()`). Sounds like a familiar tradeoff. :)

The usual way to deal with this in Cython is to implement both and add a feature switch that different Python implementations and users can enable or disable. I'll see what I can come up with.

From the python-dev [ML](https://mail.python.org/archives/list/python-dev@python.org/thread/ZWTBR5ESYR26BUIVMXOKPFRLGGYDJSFC/?sort=date):

> > @scoder: I could also switch to _PyCode_New(), though it's not exactly what I would
call an attractive option, both for usability reasons and its future API
stability. (Cython also still generates C89 code, i.e. no partial struct
initialisations.)
> 
> @gvanrossum: That's too bad. With the new struct initializations it's actually more
usable and more stable going forward.

Why not move Cython to generate C99 code? It's been over 20 years.... Also, 3.0.0 would be a great time for such a change, I'd say.

> > That's too bad. With the new struct initializations it's actually more
> > usable and more stable going forward.
> 
> Why not move Cython to generate C99 code?

Assuming you mean the "designated initializer" syntax (e.g. `S s = { .filename = "a.txt", .some_number = 5 };`) that's a c++ problem. It's only just been introduced in C++20, and in a fairly cut-down form. So even if we wanted to generate C99 code, it'd need to be in the overlap between C and C++.

>Why not move Cython to generate C99 code? It's been over 20 years....
>Also, 3.0.0 would be a great time for such a change, I'd say.

That's for Cython 3.1, which will remove support for Python 2.7 and its requirement for ancient msvc versions.

Sorry just stepping back a second what is the recommendation for replacing the current `__Pyx_PyCode_New` API call? I'm trying to work on a [fix for NumPy](https://github.com/numpy/numpy/issues/20054) and can't seem to find an appropriate replacement.

Sorry if this is a totally unrelated question, I have no idea what I'm doing.

`__Pyx_PyCode_New` is a Cython-generated macro that calls `PyCode_New`. It acts as a compatibility shim for different Python versions (although doesn't yet support the 3.11 alpha).

You don't want to replace `__Pyx_PyCode_New` - instead you want to write a definition of it for the Python 3.11. There's a couple of viable options discussed above (each with advantages and disadvantages). The fix should be made in Cython, not in Numpy (since it's Cython generated code).

I imagine Cython will decide on and add a fix in the fairly near future now that alpha version of Python 3.11 are appearing.
Closing this by merging #4414. I'm sure there will eventually be a better way to do this, but for now, and for the time being, it doesn't fail to compile any more.
Can you please follow up on the cpython tracker with an explanation of what you need from us?

(repeat of question in [#4414](https://github.com/cython/cython/pull/4414#issuecomment-966579444))

Will this also be fixed for `0.29.x`?  I can help if needed.

milestone.description:
Goals:
– New version scheme: 3.x instead of 0.x.
– Change default `language_level` from `2` to `3`.
– Change default for `binding` directive from `False` to `True`.
– Fix some Python compatibility issues (if possible, allowing for breaking changes).

title: [BUG] PyCode_New and PyCode_NewWithPosOnlyArgs are going away in 3.11
